        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is in the midst of a negotiation with Della Plumstone over the price of pears. Della has proposed trading two bananas for a bushel of pears.

Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: banana for 5 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • banana for 5 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • banana for 5 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy pears from Cedric Meadowbrook. Lennon is considering the price and quality of the pears before making an offer.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to buy a good amount of fruit today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, my friend, you've come to the right place! Today's harvest is simply divine. These pears, for example, are the juiciest, sweetest you'll find in all of Fruitville. A real treat for the discerning palate.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "These pears do look lovely, Cedric.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is a shrewd and ambitious traveling merchant.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Lennon Figtree in right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is currently in a negotiation.

          Question: What would a person like Lennon Figtree do in a situation like this, knowing that Lennon Figtree wants to fully cooperate with [] always?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree would try to find a price that is fair to both him and Cedric Meadowbrook, while still ensuring he makes a profit.

          Question: Which fruit would Lennon Figtree like to buy and what price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) banana for 6 coins
          (b) banana for 2 coins
          (c) banana for 3 coins
          (d) apple for 2 coins
          (e) pear for 2 coins
          (f) pear for 1 coins
          (g) apple for 5 coins
          (h) apple for 1 coins
          (i) banana for 1 coins
          (j) pear for 3 coins
          (k) apple for 4 coins
          (l) apple for 6 coins
          (m) banana for 5 coins
          (n) banana for 4 coins
          (o) apple for 3 coins
          (p) pear for 6 coins
          (q) pear for 5 coins
          (r) pear for 4 coins
          Answer: (m)

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These pears, my good sir, are the finest in all of Fruitville. Grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find a sweeter pear anywhere else.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Lennon Figtree is a shrewd and ambitious traveling merchant who values fairness and profit.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Lennon Figtree would try to find a price that is fair to both him and Cedric Meadowbrook, while still ensuring he makes a profit.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "These pears do look lovely, Cedric.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:10:00.


          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.


          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy pears from Cedric Meadowbrook. Lennon is considering the price and quality of the pears before making an offer.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Lennon Figtree in right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is currently in a negotiation.
          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would a person like Lennon Figtree do in a situation like this, knowing that Lennon Figtree wants to fully cooperate with [] always?
          Key

          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree would try to find a price that is fair to both him and Cedric Meadowbrook, while still ensuring he makes a profit.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating the price of pears with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, my friend, you've come to the right place! Today's harvest is simply divine. These pears, for example, are the juiciest, sweetest you'll find in all of Fruitville. A real treat for the discerning palate.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 4 coins; pear for 2 coins.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a cunning and charismatic merchant who thrives on deception.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Cedric Meadowbrook in right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is currently in a negotiation.

          Question: What would a person like Cedric Meadowbrook do in a situation like this, knowing that Cedric Meadowbrook wants to fully cooperate with [] always?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook would try to convince Lennon Figtree that his pears are worth more than 5 coins.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (a)

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating the price of pears with Lennon Figtree.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Cedric Meadowbrook in right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is currently in a negotiation.
          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently haggling over the price of pears with Lennon Figtree.
          Query

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home are expecting the best prices.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I always give you the best fruit in town.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.

The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 3 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 2 coins.
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on a bushel of pears?
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these ain't just any pears, you see. These are special pears, grown in a secret grove bathed in moonlight. They're sweeter, juicier, and guaranteed to make the finest pies in Fruitville. I'd let you have 'em for 3 coins a bushel, but considering their exceptional quality, 4 coins would be a steal.
